thread.title: Every big Oregon Coast earthquake since 7845 B.C., charted. Hint: We're due
thread.title_full: Every big Oregon Coast earthquake since 7845 B.C., charted. Hint: We're due | OregonLive.com

author: Stuart Tomlinson | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Every big Oregon Coast earthquake since 7845 B.C., charted. Hint: We're due
text:
A U.S. Geological Survey study of core samples from the ocean floor, taken near the Juan de Fuca fault off the coast of Oregon, shows that large, so-called megaquakes of more than 7.5 magnitude have occurred on average every 246 years during the past 10,000 years.
An interactive chart and timeline worked up from the USGS data by The Oregonian/OregonLive's Mark Graves shows the last one was -- gulp -- 315 years ago.
The history of large earthquakes in the Cascadia subduction zone made national news earlier this yea r when an article in the New Yorker went viral, prompting a flurry of stories about preparedness and the danger looming off the coast of the Pacific Northwest.
USGS scientists studied the core samples looking for turbidites -- deposits of sediments that flow along the ocean floor during large earthquakes.
According the study, scientist spent 30 days at sea and collected more than 102 core samples, in addition to using 60 older cores, to complete their study.
-- Stuart Tomlinson
